On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 1:15 PM, Barry Norton <barrynorton@...> wrote:
>
>
> On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 11:11 AM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>>
>> RDF, in the quest for web-intelligibility, does not seem to cope very
>> well with the ambiguous and messy reality of The Web. This has led to
>> a lot of controversy and demands from the RDF community for solutions
>> to problems that apparently don't exist for REST or anyone else
>> outside of 'RDF land' - a good example of a this is range-14.
>
>
> httpRange-14, as its name suggests, is an HTTP issue not an RDF one. RDF is
> useful to describe informational and non-informational resources in a
> uniform way. Linked Data, in using RDF with HTTP, encounters this issue but
> does not cause it.

That weird forced distinction between informational vs
non-informational resources is fabricated by RDF-think.  HTTP has no
requirement to make this distinction otherwise, therefore range-14 is
addressing a would-be-non-issue-for-http that is inflicted on the web
by RDF.

Basically, in range-14, the issue for HTTP is that it is the
unfortunate victim of RDF's web-insanity being taken way too
seriously.

Cheers,
Mike
